questions.question: Liquidtight flexible metal conduit (LFMC) is permitted to be used as an equipment grounding conductor when what length or less?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 350.60, LFMC is permitted as an equipment grounding conductor when 6 feet (1.8 m) or less and the circuit conductors are protected by overcurrent devices rated 60 amperes or less.

questions.question: PVC conduit (Schedule 40) is permitted in what locations?
options: Concealed and exposed locations, subject to physical damage restrictions
questions.explanation: Per NEC 352.10, PVC conduit is permitted in concealed and exposed locations with certain restrictions on physical damage and support requirements.

questions.question: PVC conduit exposed to sunlight must be identified as what?
options: Sunlight resistant or protected from sunlight
questions.explanation: Per NEC 352.10(G), PVC conduit exposed to sunlight shall be listed as sunlight resistant or be protected from sunlight by design of the raceway or mounting.

questions.question: What is the expansion rate consideration for PVC conduit runs exceeding 25 feet?
options: Must use expansion fittings where temperature change exceeds 30°F
questions.explanation: Per NEC 352.44, expansion fittings shall be provided to compensate for thermal expansion and contraction where the length change is expected to exceed 6 mm (¼ inch).

questions.question: Type MC cable must be secured within what distance of each box or termination?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 330.30(B), Type MC cable shall be secured within 12 inches (300 mm) of every box, cabinet, fitting, or other cable termination.

questions.question: Type MC cable shall be supported at intervals not exceeding what distance?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 330.30(C), Type MC cable shall be supported at intervals not exceeding 6 feet (1.8 m).

questions.question: Type AC cable (BX) must be secured within what distance of each box or termination?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 320.30(B), Type AC cable shall be secured within 12 inches (300 mm) of every outlet box, junction box, cabinet, or fitting.

questions.question: Type AC cable (BX) requires what additional component inside the armor at terminations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 320.40, an insulating bushing or equivalent protection (anti-short bushing) shall be provided between conductors and armor at terminations.

questions.question: A junction box cover must be accessible. What does accessible mean in this context?
options: Capable of being removed without damaging the building structure
questions.explanation: Per NEC 314.29, junction boxes shall be installed so that the wiring can be rendered accessible without removing any part of the building or exposing the conductors.

questions.question: What is the maximum box fill volume for a 4-inch square metal box with a 1-1/2 inch depth?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 314.16(A), a 4-inch square metal box with a 1-1/2 inch depth has a volume of 21.0 cubic inches.

questions.question: What is the volume allowance for a #14 AWG conductor in box fill calculations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 314.16(B), each #14 AWG conductor requires 2.00 cubic inches of box volume.

questions.question: When counting conductors for box fill, how many conductor volumes does a device (switch or receptacle) require?
options: 2 conductor volumes based on largest conductor connected to device
questions.explanation: Per NEC 314.16(B)(4), a single volume allowance based on the largest conductor connected to a device shall be made for each yoke or strap containing one or more devices.

questions.question: All equipment grounding conductors in a box count as how many conductors for box fill?
options: One conductor volume based on largest EGC
questions.explanation: Per NEC 314.16(B)(5), a single volume allowance based on the largest equipment grounding conductor entering the box shall be made for all equipment grounding conductors.

questions.question: Cable clamps in a box count as how many conductor volumes?
options: One or more conductor volumes based on largest conductor
One conductor volume total for all clamps
questions.explanation: Per NEC 314.16(B)(2), a single volume allowance based on the largest conductor in the box shall be made for one or more cable clamps.

questions.question: What is the minimum length of free conductor required at each box or device?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 300.14, at least 6 inches (150 mm) of free conductor, measured from the point where it emerges from its raceway or cable sheath, shall be left at each outlet and switch point.

questions.question: What is the minimum length of free conductor required to extend outside the box opening for splices or device terminations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 300.14, conductors shall extend at least 3 inches (75 mm) outside the box opening for splices and terminations.

questions.question: Conductors in vertical raceways shall be supported at intervals not exceeding what, based on conductor size?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 300.19(A) and Table 300.19(A), conductors in vertical raceways shall be supported at intervals not greater than those specified in the table based on conductor size.

questions.question: Underground service conductors that are not encased in concrete must be buried at least how deep under a driveway?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 300.5, direct burial cables or conductors not in rigid conduit under driveways require a minimum burial depth of 24 inches.

questions.question: Underground conductors in rigid metal conduit (RMC) must be buried at least how deep?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 300.5, circuits in rigid metal conduit (RMC) require a minimum burial depth of 6 inches.

questions.question: Underground conductors in PVC conduit must be buried at least how deep under a lawn?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 300.5, circuits in rigid PVC conduit require a minimum burial depth of 18 inches.

questions.question: When conductors emerge from the ground, protection must extend to at least what height above finished grade?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 300.5(D), direct-buried conductors or cables emerging from the ground shall be protected by enclosures or raceways extending from the minimum cover depth to a point at least 8 feet above finished grade.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance for service drop conductors over a residential driveway?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.24(B)(1), service drop conductors shall have a minimum clearance of 12 feet over residential property and driveways.

questions.question: What is the minimum clearance for service drop conductors over a public street?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.24(B)(4), service drop conductors shall have a minimum clearance of 18 feet over public streets, alleys, roads, and driveways subject to truck traffic.

questions.question: Service entrance conductors must be installed above the point of attachment. What is the minimum clearance above the roof?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.24(A), overhead service conductors shall have a vertical clearance of not less than 3 feet (900 mm) above the roof surface, with exceptions for low-slope roofs and other conditions.

questions.question: Service entrance cables must be supported within what distance of the service head?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.51(A), service cables shall be supported within 12 inches (300 mm) of the service head and at intervals not exceeding 30 inches (750 mm).

questions.question: A service point is defined as what?
options: The point of connection between utility facilities and the premises wiring
questions.explanation: Per NEC Article 100, the service point is the point of connection between the facilities of the serving utility and the premises wiring.

questions.question: The service disconnecting means must be located where?
options: At the nearest accessible location to the point of entrance of service conductors
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.70(A)(1), the service disconnecting means shall be installed at a readily accessible location either outside the building or inside nearest the point of entrance of the service conductors.

questions.question: A dwelling unit's disconnecting means is required to be installed in a location that is what?
options: On the exterior or inside at nearest point of entrance
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.85, for dwelling units, an emergency disconnect shall be installed in a readily accessible outdoor location.

questions.question: What marking is required on an emergency disconnect for a dwelling unit?
options: 'Emergency Disconnect, Service Disconnect, or a similar marking'
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.85(E), the emergency disconnect shall be marked as 'EMERGENCY DISCONNECT', 'SERVICE DISCONNECT', or a similar approved marking.

questions.question: What is the minimum rating for a single service disconnect for a dwelling?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 230.79(C), a single service disconnect for a one-family dwelling shall have a rating of not less than 100 amperes, 3-wire.

questions.question: AFCI protection is required for branch circuits supplying outlets in what areas of dwelling units?
options: Kitchens, family rooms, dining rooms, living rooms, parlors, libraries, dens, bedrooms, sunrooms, recreation rooms, closets, hallways, laundry areas, or similar rooms or areas
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.12(A), AFCI protection is required for 120-volt branch circuits supplying outlets and devices in the listed areas, which covers most living spaces except bathrooms and garages.

questions.question: AFCI and GFCI protection are not required for what type of device per NEC exceptions?
options: Fire alarm systems not readily accessible
questions.explanation: Per NEC exceptions, certain fire alarm circuits, security systems, and equipment that are not readily accessible or require continuous power have AFCI and GFCI protection exceptions.

questions.question: Tamper-resistant receptacles are required in what locations?
options: All dwelling unit receptacles, child care facilities, pediatric areas in hospitals, and other specific locations
questions.explanation: Per NEC 406.12, tamper-resistant receptacles shall be installed in dwelling units, guest rooms, child care facilities, pediatric areas in hospitals, and other locations where children may be present.

questions.question: Weather-resistant receptacles are required in what locations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 406.9, receptacles installed in damp locations and wet locations shall be a listed weather-resistant type.

questions.question: Receptacle outlet covers in wet locations must provide what type of protection?
options: Protection when the attachment plug is inserted or removed
Listed extra-duty in-use cover providing protection with plug inserted
questions.explanation: Per NEC 406.9(B)(1), receptacles in wet locations shall have an enclosure that is weatherproof whether or not the attachment plug cap is inserted, requiring an 'in-use' or 'while-in-use' cover.

questions.question: Outdoor receptacles must be located not more than how many feet from the grade-level entrance to a dwelling?
options: One outlet at front and back is required
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(E)(1), at least one receptacle outlet readily accessible from grade shall be installed at the front and back of each dwelling unit with direct access to grade.

questions.question: A dedicated 20-ampere circuit is required for what appliance in a dwelling?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.11(C)(2), in addition to the number of branch circuits required, at least one 20-ampere branch circuit shall be provided for the laundry receptacle outlet.

questions.question: How many 20-amp small appliance circuits are required in a dwelling kitchen?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(B)(1), a minimum of two 20-ampere small-appliance branch circuits shall serve the receptacle outlets in the kitchen, pantry, breakfast room, dining room, or similar area.

questions.question: Countertop receptacles in kitchens must be spaced so that no point along the wall line is more than how far from a receptacle?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(C)(1), receptacle outlets shall be installed so that no point along the wall line is more than 24 inches (600 mm) measured horizontally from a receptacle outlet.

questions.question: A receptacle outlet is required for any countertop space that is how wide or wider?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(C)(1), countertop receptacle outlets shall be installed for each wall counter space 12 inches (300 mm) or wider.

questions.question: Island countertops require a receptacle if the counter is how large?
options: 24 x 12 inches minimum with no dimension less than 12 inches
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(C)(2), at least one receptacle outlet shall be installed for each island countertop space with a long dimension of 24 inches (600 mm) or greater and a short dimension of 12 inches (300 mm) or greater.

questions.question: Peninsula countertops require a receptacle if they have a long dimension of at least how many inches?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(C)(3), at least one receptacle outlet shall be installed for each peninsular countertop space with a long dimension of 24 inches (600 mm) or greater and a short dimension of 12 inches (300 mm) or greater.

questions.question: Bathroom receptacles must be supplied by a circuit that serves what?
options: Only the bathroom where the receptacle is located
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.11(C)(3), the 20-ampere bathroom branch circuit shall be permitted to supply a single bathroom or multiple bathrooms.

questions.question: At least one bathroom receptacle must be located within what distance of the outside edge of each basin?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(D), at least one wall receptacle outlet shall be installed within 3 feet (900 mm) of the outside edge of each basin.

questions.question: Hallways 10 feet or longer require how many receptacle outlets?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(H), in dwelling units, hallways of 10 feet (3.0 m) or more in length shall have at least one receptacle outlet.

questions.question: A garage receptacle outlet is required for each vehicle space. True or False?
options: True - one GFCI outlet for each car space
False - at least one receptacle per attached garage is required
True - one outlet per 200 sq ft
questions.explanation: Per NEC 210.52(G)(1), at least one receptacle outlet shall be installed in each attached garage and each detached garage with electric power.

questions.question: What is the maximum height for a receptacle outlet serving a washing machine?
questions.explanation: The NEC does not specify a maximum height for laundry receptacles, but they are typically installed at accessible heights. Local codes may have specific requirements.

questions.question: A dwelling unit with 2000 square feet of living space requires how much general lighting load for calculation purposes?
questions.explanation: Per NEC Table 220.12, dwelling units require 3 VA per square foot for general lighting load calculations. 2000 sq ft × 3 VA = 6000 VA.

questions.question: How many VA must be included for each small appliance circuit in dwelling load calculations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 220.52(A), a load of not less than 1500 VA shall be included for each 2-wire small-appliance branch circuit.

questions.question: How many VA must be included for the laundry circuit in dwelling load calculations?
questions.explanation: Per NEC 220.52(B), a load of not less than 1500 VA shall be included for the laundry branch circuit.
